abstract.text: Process keyboard interactions asynchronously in your iOS browser app’s text view.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Integrating custom browser text views with UIKit

inlineContent.text: iOS apps that draw custom text views adopt the
protocol to inform the text input system about changes in state related to text input and selection.

In browser apps, the text input system might need information that your app prepares by communicating with an extension asynchronously, or information that the app prepares by executing Javascript from a web site.
In these situations, your text view additionally adopts the
protocol.

The text input system uses this protocol to make asynchronous requests for information about the text in your view, and to supply information about gestures that support text interactions, including selecting text and modifying the selection.
isn’t a complete replacement for
, so a custom view that participates in the text system needs to conform to both protocols.

Return

The system tells your text view which writing direction the person is using to input text with
Implement the
method to accept key events from the text input system, which you interpret to insert characters and perform actions for key combinations that the text system doesn’t interpret.
Asynchronously process the key event, and call the completion handler when you’re done, passing
in the second parameter if you handled the event,
otherwise.
The system calls
multiple times for one keypress:
Once when someone initially presses the key and it enters the
state.
Zero or more times for repeated entry if the key remains pressed down, in which case
is
Once when someone releases the key and it re-enters the
state.
If you don’t handle the key event and return
from the completion handler, call the delegate’s
method to give the system an opportunity to handle the event.
Your text view needs to call the completion handler for each key event it receives, to indicate to the text system that it’s ready for the next event.
The operating system processes key events on a serial queue, so if you don’t call the completion handler you block key input to your app.
Additionally, implement
to discover when someone presses and releases the shift key and when someone engages and disengages the caps lock.
Tell the text system what text is in a given range in your text view with
In your implementation of
, report the difference between two text positions, counting the number of insertion points (locations that the text caret can adopt) between the text positions.
A negative value means that the first position is after the second position; zero means they are the same position; and a positive value means that the first position is before the second position.

content.text: Select text and respond to selection changes

inlineContent.text: When the operating system detects that someone is starting a gesture in your text view, it sends your text view
, passing the type of gesture it detects and the location of the gesture in your view’s coordinate system.
To permit the gesture to proceed, return
from this method; otherwise, return
If you permit the gesture, then as someone selects text in your text view, the text system sends your text view one of the following methods, depending on the gesture:
The gesture moves the text selection caret in the given direction.
The gesture locates the text selection caret at the given point.
The gesture updates the selection to the text contained at the given granularity and point.
The gesture adjusts the selection to include the text at the given point.
The operating system changed the point at which it’s tracking the gesture.
The gesture changes the selection to the text between the given points.
The gesture adjusts the selection’s start or end boundary to the text at the given point.
The view’s
property needs to contain the selection and the
property needs to contain the range of the selection.
If the selection caret is in the document, then
has zero length.
If someone hasn’t selected any text, both of these properties need to be
If the selection is at the beginning of the text document, then return
as the value for
; otherwise, return
As someone continues their text-selection gesture, you need to update the geometry of the selection so that the text system draws the selection UI correctly.
Implement
and
to provide the selection geometry to the text system.
Implement
to get notified when someone modifies the selection.
Your text view also needs to support marked text.
Marked text
is very similar to selected text, and represents a range of text proposed for insertion that someone hasn’t yet confirmed they want.
Use distinct display styles for marked and selected text.
The text system calls
when someone deletes text using the backspace or delete keys.
The direction indicates whether to delete text ahead of or behind the insertion point.
You support autocorrect in your text view by implementing
, replacing the original text in your text storage with the
string.
When the text system requires extra context around the current selection to make autocorrect suggestions, it calls
In the completion handler, return a
that includes the complete sentence that contains the selection.
If the selection is at a sentence boundary, also include the preceding sentence.
Additionally, implement
to accept suggested text from the text system as a
, for example, when someone uses AutoFill to complete the value for a text field.

Some text interactions — including placing the text cursor in a view and updating the selection range — require a text view to scroll automatically so the person can see the text with which they’re interacting.
When the text system needs to automatically scroll your text view, it sends
, with a point in the coordinate space of your text view’s
that needs to become visible.
When the person completes the interaction, the text system sends

When someone uses Apple Pencil to enter handwritten text into a text view, text alternatives provide alternate interpretations of the person’s input that the person can choose to replace the transcribed text.
To support text alternatives in your browser text view, implement these methods:
Add text alternatives to the text view for the currently selected text.
Insert the given text or one of its alternatives.
Remove the text alternatives for the currently selected text.
Supply the available text alternatives.

content.text: Respond to someone dismissing the keyboard

inlineContent.text: On iPad, a person can dismiss the on-screen keyboard from a control on the keyboard UI, which ends the current text-editing session.
Implement
to react to the person dismissing the keyboard while your text view is active.

If the browser view that hosts your text control needs to retain first-responder status after someone dismisses the keyboard, for example, to provide keyboard-driven scrolling, or it needs to execute Javascript when someone finishes editing text, use this method to remove keyboard focus from the text control without resigning first-responder status.
